conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, and C will change when the light source moves from directly above to the right above the objects.

In the first image, there is a small birdcage with shadow A, a glass object with shadow B, and a wooden item with shadow C. The shadows appear directly beneath or nearly beneath each object, suggesting the light source is positioned roughly overhead.
Shadow position shifts in the opposite direction from the light movement.
Shadow size changes based on the object's distance from the surface and light angle.
Shadow sharpness depends on the light source size and distance.
In the second image, the light has moved right.
Shadow A (Birdcage) has moved to the left and enlarged slightly, becoming more oval-shaped due to the angled light.
Shadow B (Glass Object) has moved leftward and appears slightly elongated in the direction opposite to the light source.
Shadow C (Wooden Spoon/Scoop) has shifted to the left and elongated, appearing more stretched compared to the original.

When the light source moves to the right, all shadows shift left, elongate in the direction away from the light source, and the further an object is from the surface, the more dramatic its shadow's position change and elongation.

When the light source moves to the right above the objects, all shadows (A, B, and C) will shift to the left, elongate/stretch in the direction away from the light source, and the shape of each shadow will distort based on the object's 3D form.
